title: 107_hr3885
content: The Act titled "Seafood Safety and Mercury Screening Act of 2002" amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to establish a tolerance for methyl mercury in seafood. This includes adding methyl mercury in seafood as a concern under section 402(a)(2)(A) and introducing a new section for tolerance levels of methyl mercury in seafood. The Seafood Safety and Mercury Screening Act of 2002 requires the Secretary to establish a tolerance for methyl mercury in seafood within one year of enactment. Seafood exceeding this tolerance is deemed unsafe. The Secretary must ensure the tolerance is safe and can modify or revoke it if necessary. The term 'safe' means the Secretary has determined the tolerance for methyl mercury in seafood is safe. The Seafood Safety and Mercury Screening Act of 2002 mandates the Secretary to establish a tolerance for methyl mercury in seafood to ensure safety for pregnant women, infants, and children. A sampling system for ongoing seafood testing must be implemented within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The Seafood Safety and Mercury Screening Act of 2002 requires the establishment of a sampling system for ongoing seafood testing to ensure compliance with methyl mercury tolerance levels. Additionally, a national public education program will be implemented to raise awareness about methyl mercury in seafood among the public and health professionals. The Seafood Safety and Mercury Screening Act of 2002 mandates the provision of information to health professionals for better diagnosis and treatment of mercury-related illness. It also requires the development and distribution of regional and national advisories on methyl mercury in seafood to promote public awareness. The Seafood Safety and Mercury Screening Act of 2002 mandates the development of standardized formats for advisories on methyl mercury in seafood and the incorporation of State and local advisories into the national public education program. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must consider the National Academy of Sciences' findings on methyl mercury exposure and seafood in relation to the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. Additionally, a report is required to be issued. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, through the Commissioner of Food and Drugs, must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. The report will detail the progress in establishing the required tolerance amendments and include information on research conducted regarding the tolerance.
